title: Menopause - Things you can do
description: Find out what you can do to help reduce menopause and perimenopause symptoms, including how to stay healthy and how to ease hot flushes.
cleaned_text: Eating well, exercising and [looking after your mental wellbeing](https://www2.hse.ie/mental-health/) can help with symptoms during perimenopause and menopause. It can also help you keep as well as possible in the future. Do - eat a [healthy diet](https://www2.hse.ie/healthy-eating-active-living/nutrition/) - have calcium-rich food like milk, yogurt and kale to keep your bones healthy - exercise regularly and try including weight-bearing activities where your feet and legs support your weight like walking, running or dancing - do relaxing things like yoga, tai chi or meditation - get plenty of rest, including keeping to [regular sleep routines](https://www2.hse.ie/mental-health/issues/sleep-problems/#tips-for-better-sleep) - talk to other people going through the same thing, like family, friends or colleagues - talk to a GP before taking herbal supplements or complementary medicines Don't - do not smoke - [get help to quit smoking](https://www2.hse.ie/quit-smoking/) - do not drink more than the [recommended low-risk alcohol guidelines](https://www2.hse.ie/wellbeing/alcohol/improve-your-health/weekly-low-risk-alcohol-guidelines.html) How to ease mood changes It's common to have mood swings, low mood and anxiety around the time of menopause and perimenopause. You can try to: - get plenty of rest - exercise regularly - it increases endorphins which helps your mood - do relaxing activities - make time for activities you enjoy [Cognitive behavioural therapy (CBT)](https://www2.hse.ie/mental-health/services-support/talking-therapies/#cognitive-behavioural-therapy) is a type of talking therapy that can help with a low mood and feelings of anxiety. Other [treatments](https://www2.hse.ie/conditions/menopause/menopause-treatment/) are also available, including [hormone replacement therapy (HRT)](https://www2.hse.ie/conditions/hrt/). [Antidepressants](https://www2.hse.ie/conditions/antidepressants/) may help if you've been diagnosed with depression. How to ease hot flushes and night sweats If you experience hot flushes and night sweats because of menopause, there are things you can do that may help. You can: - wear light clothing - keep your bedroom cool at night - take a cool shower, use a fan or have a cold drink - try to [reduce your stress level](https://www2.hse.ie/mental-health/issues/stress/) - avoid or reduce potential triggers, such as spicy food, caffeine, hot drinks, smoking and alcohol [exercise](https://www2.hse.ie/healthy-eating-active-living/exercise/)or do physical activity regularly Weight gain can be an issue during menopause. Weight loss should be gradual - combine healthy eating with keeping active. [CBT](https://www2.hse.ie/mental-health/services-support/talking-therapies/#cognitive-behavioural-therapy) can also help manage hot flushes. It can also help with sleep problems. Learn more about [hot flushes](https://www2.hse.ie/conditions/hot-flushes/) How to ease vaginal dryness There are vaginal moisturisers or lubricants you can get without a prescription at a pharmacy. You can talk to a pharmacist in private if you'd like help deciding which moisturiser is right for you. If you're using condoms during sex, do not use oil-based lubricant as this can damage condoms. You can use a water-based lubricant. There are other treatments for vaginal dryness that a GP can prescribe, such as HRT or hormonal treatment (creams, pessaries, gel or vaginal rings). Keep up to date with your screening tests during and after menopause. There are [things you can do to make a cervical screening test easier](https://www2.hse.ie/screening-and-vaccinations/cervical-screening/what-happens.html#easier). Find out about [treatment for menopause](https://www2.hse.ie/conditions/menopause/menopause-treatment/) [Vaginal dryness and how to treat vaginal dryness yourself](https://www2.hse.ie/conditions/vaginal-dryness/) Protecting against weak bones Women who have been through menopause are at an increased risk of developing osteoporosis (weak bones). This is because of the lower level of oestrogen in the body. Taking [HRT](https://www2.hse.ie/conditions/menopause/menopause-treatment/#hormone-replacement-therapy-hrt) can reduce the risk of osteoporosis. You can also try to: - exercise regularly, including weight-bearing exercises, where your feet and legs support your weight (like walking, running or dancing) and resistance exercises (for example, using weights) - eat a healthy diet that includes plenty of fruit, vegetables and sources of calcium, such as milk, yogurt and kale - take a [calcium](https://www2.hse.ie/conditions/vitamins-and-minerals/calcium/)supplement if you're vegan or cannot get enough calcium through your diet - talk to your GP about this - get some sunlight on your skin as this triggers the production of vitamin D, which can help keep your bones healthy - take a [vitamin D](https://www2.hse.ie/conditions/vitamins-and-minerals/vitamin-d/)supplement - talk to your GP about this [get help to quit smoking](https://www2.hse.ie/quit-smoking/)and [cut down on alcohol](https://www2.hse.ie/wellbeing/alcohol/improve-your-health/) Get screened Keep up to date with your screening tests and appointments during and after menopause. These are: [cervical screening](https://www2.hse.ie/cervical-screening/)(age 25 to 65) [breast screening](https://www2.hse.ie/breast-screening/)(between age 50 and 69) [bowel screening](https://www2.hse.ie/screening-and-vaccinations/bowel-screening/bowel-screening-information.html)(from age 60 to 69)
